Article_title: A validation study for the utility of serum microRNA as a diagnostic and prognostic marker in patients with osteosarcoma
description: This text appears to be a summary of a scientific study investigating the role of various microRNAs (miRNAs) in osteosarcoma and other bone tumors, as well as their potential as biomarkers for disease outcomes and differentiation from other bone conditions.Here's a breakdown of the key points from the summary:**Patient Characteristics:**- The osteosarcoma group included 30 patients (20 male, 10 female) with a mean age of 24 years.- All had high-grade osteosarcoma, with most tumors located in the appendicular skeleton.- No distant metastasis at presentation, with various tumor sizes and stages.- After neoadjuvant chemotherapy, most patients underwent surgery followed by adjuvant chemotherapy.- The follow-up period averaged 108 months, with some cases of local recurrence and distant metastasis, and some deaths due to the disease.**Survival Rates and miRNA Levels:**- Certain miRNAs (miR-146a-5p, miR-1260a, miR-487b-3p) were associated with improved overall survival.- Others (miR-1260a, miR-487b-3p, miR-1260b, miR-4758-3p) were linked to better distant metastasis-free survival.- High levels of miR-1260a, miR-1260b, and miR-4758-3p were associated with improved disease-free survival.**Differentiation from Other Bone Tumors:**- Serum miR-1261 levels were higher in osteosarcoma patients compared to healthy controls and those with other bone tumors, suggesting its potential as a biomarker for osteosarcoma.**Effect of miR-1261 on Cellular Viability and Proliferation:**- Inhibition of miR-1261 did not significantly affect cell viability or proliferation in osteosarcoma cell lines, although there were some non-significant trends observed.**Effect of miR-1261 on Target Genes:**- Inhibition of miR-1261 increased mRNA levels of CDH6 and SETD2 in osteosarcoma cells, while addition of miR-1261 decreased mRNA levels of KIF26B and SETD2, indicating that miR-1261 may regulate these genes.Overall, the study suggests that certain miRNAs may serve as biomarkers for osteosarcoma prognosis and could help differentiate it from other bone tumors. Additionally, miR-1261 in particular may play a role in the molecular pathways of osteosarcoma, although its exact impact on cell viability and proliferation is not clear-cut based on the data provided.

Article_title: Meta-Analysis of Heat-Stressed Transcriptomes Using the Public Gene Expression Database from Human and Mouse Samples
description: The text provided appears to be an excerpt from a scientific paper or report detailing the methodology and results of a study on gene expression in response to heat shock (HS) in humans and mice. The study involves high-throughput sequencing data analysis to identify genes that are upregulated or downregulated in response to HS. Here is a summary of the sections provided:**2. Results****2.1. Overview of Analysis Scheme**- The analysis scheme is outlined, with subsequent sections detailing various aspects of the study.**2.2. Characteristics of HS-Related High-Throughput Sequencing Data**- The study collected gene expression data from public databases, including 66 Sequence Read Archive (SRA) IDs and 564 pairs of gene expression data from human and mouse samples.- The data included various sequencing methods like RNA-seq and Ribo-seq.- Metadata for the collected data is available in figshare files.**2.3. Verification of Upregulated and Downregulated Genes in Each Organism**- Gene expression was quantified, and expression ratios (HN-ratios) were calculated.- Genes were classified as upregulated, downregulated, or unchanged based on a defined threshold.- HN-scores were calculated and visualized in scatter plots.- Gene set enrichment analysis was performed using Metascape, identifying enriched GO terms for upregulated and downregulated gene groups.**2.4. Identification of Common Upregulated or Downregulated Genes in Human and Mouse**- Genes common to both human and mouse samples were identified.- Mouse Genome Informatics (MGI) was used to convert human gene symbols to mouse orthologs.- A scatter plot was created to evaluate the distribution of HN-scores for the common genes.- Enrichment analysis was performed to characterize the common upregulated and downregulated genes.**2.5. Integration of HN-score, Transcription Factor-Binding Information, and Literature Information**- Enrichment analysis of transcription factor target genes was conducted, focusing on HSF1, HSF2, and PPARGC1A.- ChIP-seq data from the ChIP-Atlas database was integrated with HN-score results.- Scatter plots were used to visualize the relationship between ChIP-seq scores, HN-scores, and the number of research reports for each gene.The study aims to understand the genetic response to heat shock by analyzing gene expression data and identifying common patterns between humans and mice. The integration of various data types, including high-throughput sequencing, transcription factor-binding information, and literature data, allows for a comprehensive analysis of the genes involved in the heat shock response.
